blogs.title: Perspective
blogs.body:
Hi guys, 
My name is Okey, been a software engineer for about 6 years. It‚Äôs been great, it‚Äôs been frustrating,  it‚Äôs been awesome, it‚Äôs been annoying and it‚Äôs been rewarding ‚Ä¶ lol. I‚Äôm happy to see y‚Äôall taking this step to your new careers. This message might be a bit long. A couple of things to note though‚Ä¶as you start out you need to very important things..
- building good connections
- learning your fundamental concepts.

Every industry has nepotism but I‚Äôll say the tech industry probably has the least. I‚Äôve worked in some great places and I really no sabi anybody at all‚Ä¶unlike some other industries, the company needs your specific skills to get specific results so you need to make sure you have that on lock. Spend time studying and understanding concepts‚Ä¶it‚Äôs not about craming and just passing. With the amount of engineers coming in you need to truly understand your stuff to get ahead. You might need to study something multiple times before it sticks and that‚Äôs okay‚Ä¶it might take you 5 times and that‚Äôs fine‚Ä¶it‚Äôs not a measure of how clever you are‚Ä¶these things are not things you have known before so it‚Äôll definitely seem very strange at first but be patient with yourself..:take breaks , rest and go back and try again. Whenever you feel overwhelmed, frustrated you should take a break and just breathe.
It‚Äôll help to also have a reason for getting into this and it could be anything but it should be strong to you. It could be cause you love tech, cause you want to be financially stable and liberate yourself and your loved ones, cause you want better job security (this one is well 50-50 these days lol), cause you want to travel the world and this industry might let you do that, cause you have a product you always wanted to build‚Ä¶ anything but it should be solid and strong to you. On the days you feel down and you are crying and want to give up, remind yourself of why you started in the first place (allow yourself to cry if you have to sha‚Ä¶heard it‚Äôs therapeutic).  One thing though is to not get so focused on money..there‚Äôs money in the industry yes, you‚Äôve established that‚Ä¶now focus solely on getting yourself equipped to access it. 


Making connections is also important , amongst yourselves, your peer at altschool etc. There would be some opportunities you won‚Äôt be privy to and it‚Äôs someone from your network that‚Äôll introduce you and get your foot in the door. 
Also practice repeatedly, that‚Äôs the only way to make the concepts stick.

The story don too long sha‚Ä¶enjoy yourself, have fun, study well, practice repeatedly and feel free to embarrass Ufoma with a million messages üòÇ (na play oo). üéâ
blogs.author: Okey

blogs.title: Happy Mashujaa Day
blogs.body:
Hope you are all well.
I know that this is still exam week for you but I would still want us to try and connect  with each other (I am noticing a drift in here and I would like us to remember how we started and how connected we all were)
Today is Friday and a public holiday in Kenya :partying_face: For this reason, I would like us to do something;
First, let me teach you a little bit about our history by explaining briefly what the holiday is about. 20th October is referred to as "Mashujaa Day" in Kenya.
Mashujaa is the swahili word for 'Heroes'. So, Mashujaa day is a national holiday in Kenya which is observed as a public holiday to collectively honour all those who contributed towards the struggle for Kenya's independence or those who positively contributed in the post independence in Kenya. This means that on this day, we celebrate the resilience of our heroes, who in the midst of challenges, paved the path to our freedom.
Some of our heroes include our first president, the late Jomo Kenyatta, Dedan Kimathi, Tom Mboya.. to mention but a few. If you are keen on learning about different cultures, you can read more about these heroes.
Now, why am I sharing this with you? First, so that we can wish the Kenyans amongst us a Happy Mashujaa Day :flag-ke:.
Secondly, I know that we all have heroes- people that have either done something iconic or  inspire you in one way through their acts or basically someone that you really look up to as your hero. The person could be here in this community, they may have helped you in one way or another or the person could be an external person. I have shared some of our heroes as a Kenyan. I would like you to now share under this thread and tell us who your heroes are. You can choose to just focus on the people we have here or whoever comes to mind and you can possibly share why that person is your hero.
Okay, let's go ... Actually, I just remembered one of our heroes and legend- Eliud Kipchoge , I guess many people know him, the "No human is Limited" Kenyan-long distance runner who achieved a world record in 2022 for running the marathon within a time of 2:01:09.
Enough of Kenyan history, let us learn about our heroes today, shall we? I hope we will all try to participate in this - who knows, we may have the same heroes.
Once again, Happy Mashujaa to the Kenyans amongst us
blogs.author: Nedu

blogs.title: Scheduling: setTimeout and setInterval
blogs.body:
We may decide to execute a function not right now, but at a specific time later. That‚Äôs called ‚Äúscheduling a call‚Äù.

There are two methods for it:

setTimeout allows us to run a function once after the interval of time.
setInterval allows us to run a function repeatedly, starting after the interval of time, then repeating continuously at that interval.
These methods are not a part of JavaScript specification. But most environments have the internal scheduler and provide these methods. In particular, they are supported in all browsers and Node.js.

Follow the Link to learn more https://javascript.info/settimeout-setinterval
blogs.author: Ikenna

blogs.title: Developer Experience with Command Line Interface(CLI) Tools
blogs.body:
I think my job is about writing code, but that‚Äôs not true. My job is actually typing and making each keystroke count. Trying to save keystrokes every time by using keyboard shortcuts or tools that make the work faster and better is a niche I find very and worthwhile researching about.

My aim with this article is to help you save keystrokes by adopting better tooling and also improving your productivity and developer experience with some command-line interface CLI tools. All because I care to help the developer save more time by automating some repetitive tasks in their everyday tasks.

Embracing the new wave of CLI tools will give you great improvement in the amount of time you spend clicking around to make things happen.

Prerequisites
Things you need to know to understand this article includes:

Familiarity with terminals from the Powershell, CMD and gitbash for windows operating system to Bash, FISH, zsh, iterm on Mac and Linux respectively.
Access to CLI environments.
Scope
I will show you how I use CLI tools to improve my developer experience (DX) when creating a new GitHub repository, to uploading images to Cloudinary, to reducing the size of image files with tinify API, to doing all my netlify related tasks.

At the end of this post you will be able:

to save more time by automating repeated tasks.
making life easy for you by avoiding long and boring styles of handling repetitive tasks.
bring more joy to your workflow as you do those repetitive tasks you go through every now and then.
blogs.author: Oluwasetemi
